                        <item>
                    <title>Embryo protein may warn before miscarriage and pre-eclampsia</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2088033-embryo-protein-may-warn-before-miscarriage-and-pre-eclampsia/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 23:01:58 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        A protein that seems to help embryos implant into their mother's womb may one day warn doctors that a women might encounter problems in pregnancy                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2088033</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Computer glitch has led to incorrect advice on statins</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087983-computer-glitch-has-led-to-incorrect-advice-on-statins/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 16:35:14 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        A software error means that around a third of UK family doctors have been miscalculating whether people need medicine to avoid a heart attack since 2009                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087983</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Got dandruff? The bacteria living on your head might be to blame</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087955-got-dandruff-the-bacteria-living-on-your-head-might-be-to-blame/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 13:00:08 +0000</pubDate>
                        		<category><![CDATA[biology]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[health]]></category>
                    <description>
                        Until now, we’ve been blaming a fungus, but it turns out that too much Staphylococcus in your scalp’s ecosystem could be the cause of flaky dead skin                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087955</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>High antidepressant use could lead to UK public health disaster</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087949-high-antidepressant-use-could-lead-to-uk-public-health-disaster/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 11:34:05 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        Use of antidepressants has doubled in the past decade in the UK, and campaigners warn that it could lead to long-term withdrawal and worse mental health                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087949</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Our audience with the Pope revealed how glitz funds medicine</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg23030733-100-papal-audience-shows-how-private-cash-is-driving-precision-medicine/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 12:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        A distinguished crowd of philanthropists at the Vatican heard a well-crafted appeal for funds to boost regenerative medicine. Sumit Paul-Choudhury was there                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">http://mg23030733.100</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>The Hemsley effect: why we fall for celebrity food advice</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087418-the-hemsley-effect-why-we-fall-for-celebrity-food-advice/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 16:00:07 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        Faddish diets from insta-food stars like the Hemsley sisters thrive in a world that favours easy explanations over real science, says Anthony Warner                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087418</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Smart second skin reduces eye bags and wrinkles – or so it seems</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087378-smart-second-skin-reduces-eye-bags-and-wrinkles-or-so-it-seems/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 15:00:57 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        An invisible polymer appears to work as ‘Spanx for your face’, reducing sagging and restoring a youthful glow, but some dermatologists are sceptical                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087378</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>‘Midlife MOTs’ don’t work so why are doctors pushed to do them?</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087336-midlife-mots-dont-work-so-why-are-doctors-pushed-to-do-them/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 10:20:13 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        Over-40s health checks cost £363 million a year, and may do more harm than good. Why are people in England still being pushed to have them, asks Clare Wilson                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087336</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>If Google has nothing to hide about NHS data, why so secretive?</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg23030722-900-big-data-if-theres-nothing-to-hide-why-be-secretive/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Wed, 04 May 2016 10:12:00 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        Google's subsidiary DeepMind could use our health data to diagnose disease sooner. If it was more open, we might be happier to let it go ahead                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">http://mg23030722.900</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Revealed: Google AI has access to huge haul of NHS patient data</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2086454-revealed-google-ai-has-access-to-huge-haul-of-nhs-patient-data/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Fri, 29 Apr 2016 12:36:17 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        A data-sharing agreement obtained by New Scientist shows that Google DeepMind's collaboration with the NHS goes far beyond what it has publicly announced                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2086454</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Having an overactive immune system may prime you for depression</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg23030723-900-having-an-overactive-immune-system-may-prime-you-for-depression/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Wed, 04 May 2016 18:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        Blood tests could help doctors identify people who are at risk of severe depressive episodes, and enable them to tailor more effective treatments                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">http://mg23030723.900</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Women sleep half an hour longer than men, phone app data shows</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087231-women-sleep-half-an-hour-longer-than-men-phone-app-data-shows/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Fri, 06 May 2016 18:00:35 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        App data from 5000 sleepers have revealed that women under the age of 25 sleep the most, and that people who wake up early every day get less sleep overall                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087231</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Quick $2 test reveals if you caught a superbug in hospital</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087248-quick-2-test-reveals-if-you-caught-a-superbug-in-hospital/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Fri, 06 May 2016 18:00:25 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        A test that can detect bacterial infections within hours, rather than days, could prove a crucial weapon in the fight against antibiotic resistance                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087248</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Will brain stimulation for autism diminish my special talents?</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087213-will-brain-stimulation-for-autism-diminish-my-special-talents/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Fri, 06 May 2016 12:33:25 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        Stimulating my brain with magnetism helped me connect with others, but I can't help wondering if it could also hamper cognitive gifts, says John Elder Robison                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087213</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Cycling for more than five hours a week in Delhi is bad for you</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087087-cycling-for-more-than-five-hours-a-week-in-delhi-is-bad-for-you/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Thu, 05 May 2016 11:13:15 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        The health benefits of cycling in the most polluted cities in India and Pakistan are outweighed by the effects of the pollution after only a few hours a week                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087087</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Dragonfly wings can track radiation doses after a nuclear mishap</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087136-dragonfly-wings-can-track-radiation-doses-after-a-nuclear-mishap/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Thu, 05 May 2016 14:07:40 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        Measurements on insect wings can tell us how radiation has spread following a leak and the dose they were exposed to                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087136</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Walking and cycling are still good for you despite air pollution</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087059-walking-and-cycling-are-still-good-for-you-despite-air-pollution/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Wed, 04 May 2016 23:01:31 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        The benefits of an active commute outweigh the effects of air pollution - except in the world's most polluted cities, like Delhi                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087059</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Robotic surgeon could stitch you up after removing your appendix</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087026-robotic-surgeon-could-stitch-you-up-after-removing-your-appendix/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Wed, 04 May 2016 18:00:15 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        An autonomous robot has successfully operated on soft tissues for the first time, and may soon be doing common surgeries on the appendix and gall bladder

                     </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087026</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Antibiotics apocalypse: Tales from fighters on the front line</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg23030715-300-what-its-like-to-work-on-the-coalface-of-antibiotic-resistance/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Wed, 27 Apr 2016 18:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        Our hospitals could one day be brought to their knees by antibiotic-resistant superbugs – doctors and scientists are seeing the first glimpse of such a world                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">http://mg23030715.300</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Equally long lives for rich and poor? This dream is in retreat</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2086532-equally-long-lives-for-rich-and-poor-this-dream-is-in-retreat/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Mon, 02 May 2016 23:01:40 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        For the first time since the Victorian era, the gap in life expectancy between the top and bottom of society is widening. We must fix this, says Les Mayhew                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2086532</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Childcare and housework are what give women more heart problems</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2085396-childcare-and-housework-are-what-give-women-more-heart-problems/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Thu, 21 Apr 2016 11:23:29 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        Women are more likely to die after a heart attack than men because of traditional gender roles rather than because of biological differences between the sexes                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2085396</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Processed food bad, natural food good? We’ve got it so wrong</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2086264-processed-food-bad-natural-food-good-weve-got-it-so-wrong/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Thu, 28 Apr 2016 09:46:17 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        The trend of demonising all processed food is misguided and will only doom attempts to persuade busy consumers to eat a balanced diet, says Anthony Warner                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2086264</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Ebola virus does a total shutdown to hide before a fresh strike</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2086498-ebola-virus-does-a-total-shutdown-to-hide-before-a-fresh-strike/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Fri, 29 Apr 2016 18:00:16 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        Evidence that Ebola can lie dormant for over a year suggests that 17,000 survivors of the disease in West Africa could yet spread the virus to many others                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2086498</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Let people most affected by gene editing write CRISPR rules</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2086548-let-people-most-affected-by-gene-editing-write-crispr-rules/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Fri, 29 Apr 2016 22:33:01 +0000</pubDate>
                        		<category><![CDATA[biology]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[disease]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[genetics]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[health]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[medicine]]></category>
                    <description>
                        At a human gene editing summit in Paris today, scientists, ethicists and lawyers made the case for those affected by gene editing to call the shots                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2086548</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Muscular dystrophy is tragic, but patients aren’t always right</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2086536-muscular-dystrophy-is-tragic-but-patients-arent-always-right/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Fri, 29 Apr 2016 16:53:25 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        A US panel has rejected a new drug for muscular dystrophy. It was the right call, says Clare Wilson – it’s a myth that ground-breaking drugs are being kept from us                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2086536</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>The teenager who can’t help speaking in a French accent</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2086509-the-teenager-who-cant-help-speaking-in-a-french-accent/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Fri, 29 Apr 2016 15:59:32 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        Scanning the brain of a boy who has foreign accent syndrome has revealed that we use the cerebellum, a primitive region of our brains, to plan speech                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2086509</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Coma brain scans predict if a person will ever recover awareness</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2086335-coma-brain-scans-predict-if-a-person-will-ever-recover-awareness/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Thu, 28 Apr 2016 20:00:14 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        Detecting brain circuits that switch back and forth give a good indication of whether someone with brain damage is ever likely to recover full consciousness

                     </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2086335</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Your choice of chocolate and contraceptive affect your gut bugs</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2086320-your-choice-of-chocolate-and-contraceptive-affect-your-gut-bugs/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Thu, 28 Apr 2016 18:00:44 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        The largest ever study of microbiomes reveals 69 factors that affect the bacteria that live in your gut, including diet and everyday medicines                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2086320</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Sperm-binding beads could work as fertility aid or contraceptive</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2086187-sperm-binding-beads-could-work-as-fertility-aid-or-contraceptive/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Wed, 27 Apr 2016 18:00:50 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        Microbeads coated in a human egg protein work as a contraceptive in mice and could also be used to select the best sperm for IVF

                     </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2086187</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>State of US health: black health up, teen pregnancies down</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2085990-state-of-us-health-black-health-up-teen-pregnancies-down/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Wed, 27 Apr 2016 04:01:30 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        A report on health in the US finds that people are living longer, racial disparities are improving, but suicide, heroin use and ADHD are on the rise                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2085990</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Animals may be fed manure-bred maggots to make meat sustainable</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2085900-animals-may-be-fed-manure-bred-maggots-to-make-meat-sustainable/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Tue, 26 Apr 2016 23:01:45 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        An EU ban on the use of insect larvae in feed for farmed salmon, pigs and chicken may be relaxed after study concludes that it is safe                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2085900</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Prescription monitoring system to curb drug abuse in Australia</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2085966-prescription-monitoring-system-to-curb-drug-abuse-in-australia/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Tue, 26 Apr 2016 16:54:46 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        Real-time monitoring for drugs like OxyContin, morphine and Xanax is intended to enable doctors and pharmacists in Victoria to curb addiction and offer help                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2085966</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Sleeping away from home? Half your brain is still awake</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2085409-sleeping-away-from-home-half-your-brain-is-still-awake/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Thu, 21 Apr 2016 16:00:55 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        People often struggle to sleep their first night in an unfamiliar room, which might be because the left brain remains vigilant for threats                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2085409</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>My mind’s eye is blind – so what’s going on in my brain?</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2083706-my-minds-eye-is-blind-so-whats-going-on-in-my-brain/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Wed, 20 Apr 2016 17:00:07 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        Dustin Grinnell can't think in pictures – but people like him are teaching us a lot about how our brains process the things we see                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2083706</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>We can avoid a water crisis, but the fix will be hard to swallow</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg23030700-800-we-can-avoid-a-water-crisis-but-the-fix-will-be-hard-to-swallow/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Wed, 20 Apr 2016 18:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        High water use in drought-prone areas is folly, says Arjen Hoekstra. It's time we acknowledge that we must change what we eat and how we produce it                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">http://mg23030700.800</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Purple pain: Why grief runs so deep when a pop icon dies young</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2085622-purple-pain-why-grief-runs-so-deep-when-a-pop-icon-dies-young/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Fri, 22 Apr 2016 16:48:11 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        It is natural to be upset when a music star like Prince dies young, because of the combination of a premature death and loss of talent, says Dianna Kenny                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2085622</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Judge gene-edited crops by what they do, not how they are made</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2085611-judge-gene-edited-crops-by-what-they-do-not-how-they-are-made/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Fri, 22 Apr 2016 16:32:59 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        Europe’s regulators should focus on food safety, not on whether they meet a ridiculous definition of a genetically modified organism, says Michael Le Page                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2085611</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Why super-gonorrhoea is spreading and may soon be untreatable</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2084801-why-super-gonorrhoea-is-spreading-and-may-soon-be-untreatable/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Tue, 19 Apr 2016 09:08:19 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        England’s public health agency has launched an “incident response” because it has discovered more cases of gonorrhoea that are resistant to nearly all antibiotics                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2084801</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>The foundations of schizophrenia may be laid down in the womb</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2085432-the-foundations-of-schizophrenia-may-be-laid-down-in-the-womb/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Thu, 21 Apr 2016 16:00:03 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        People who develop schizophrenia may have been born with structural changes to the brain, caused by lower levels of an important signalling molecule                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2085432</guid>
                                                        </item>
                                                <item>
                    <title>Dementia incidence for over 65s has fallen drastically in UK men</title>
                    <link>
                    https://www.newscientist.com/article/2084859-dementia-incidence-for-over-65s-has-fallen-drastically-in-uk-men/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Tue, 19 Apr 2016 15:00:21 +0000</pubDate>
                                            <description>
                        Over the past 20 years, the incidence of dementia has fallen by 41 per cent in men – but only by 2.5 per cent in women, who are more prone to the disease                    </description>
